Like the enduring oak tree, our projects thrive through the contributions of thousands worldwide. See Projects Our Impact ¶ 290+ Open Source Projects 1300+ Software Releases 9800+ Committers 1140+ Members Our Open Source Projects ¶ The ASF is the home of the world’s most trusted open source projects in data, cloud, search, libraries, geospatial, IoT, and beyond. See All Projects Our Incubating Projects ¶ See All Incubating Projects Incubate a Project ¶ Give your project a neutral, trusted home where communities flourish — with the ASF’s expertise, tools, and support to help you succeed. Incubate Project Everyone is Welcome ¶ At The ASF, contribution is for everyone. Whether code, docs, or ideas — your +1 makes a difference. Come contribute and grow with us. New to The ASF? See Event ❮ ❯ Thank You, Sponsors ¶ The ASF is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, supported by individual and corporate donors who believe in secure software for the public good and the power of community over code. conversation.speaker: Seller
conversation.message: Hi [CTO Name], this is Alex from DeepData AI. I know you're likely busy, but I'm reaching out because we help organizations like the Apache Software Foundation streamline their complex data processing pipelines and unlock deeper insights. Are you the right person to speak with about how you manage your project data and contributions?

conversation.speaker: Buyer
conversation.message: Apache Software Foundation. Yes, I'm the CTO here. DeepData AI, you say? We're a non-profit organization driven by community contributions. Our primary focus is providing software for the public good. We're not really in the market for commercial data processing solutions.

conversation.speaker: Seller
conversation.message: I understand completely, and your mission is incredibly impressive. That's exactly why I thought of you. We work with organizations that manage vast amounts of data from diverse sources, and many of our clients are also mission-driven. DeepData AI can help automate the aggregation and analysis of your project data, release statistics, committer activity, and even identify trends in community engagement. This could free up valuable developer time to focus on core project development rather than data wrangling.

conversation.speaker: Buyer
conversation.message: "Free up developer time" is a nice thought, but our community contributors are passionate about their work. We have existing internal tools and processes for managing our data. Frankly, I'm not sure a commercial solution like yours would even integrate well with our open-source ecosystem. And what kind of pricing are we talking about for a non-profit?

conversation.speaker: Seller
conversation.message: That's a fair question, and integration is something we've designed DeepData AI to handle robustly. We have connectors for many common data sources and can often build custom ones. Regarding pricing, we have specific non-profit and academic tiers designed to be accessible. Many organizations find that the efficiency gains and enhanced insights quickly offset the investment, allowing them to achieve their mission more effectively. We could even look at a pilot program to demonstrate value before any significant commitment.

conversation.speaker: Buyer
conversation.message: A pilot program sounds like more work for my team to set up and evaluate. We're currently in the midst of a major infrastructure upgrade and our bandwidth is completely consumed by that for the next 18 months. I appreciate the offer, Alex, but this is not a priority for us right now, and the timing is simply impossible. Please send me an email with some general information, and I'll… well, I'll file it.

conversation.speaker: Seller
conversation.message: I understand completely about infrastructure priorities, [CTO Name]. It sounds like you have a lot on your plate. While I respect your current focus, I'd still like to offer a brief, 15-minute overview of how DeepData AI has helped other large open-source foundations manage their data more efficiently, even alongside existing systems. It might spark an idea for future consideration. Would you be open to a quick call next Tuesday at 10 AM EST?

conversation.speaker: Buyer
conversation.message: No, thank you, Alex. As I said, the timing is not right, and we're not actively looking for solutions in this space. I truly don't have the capacity to evaluate new technologies. I've already told you we're not interested. Goodbye.

analysis.raw:
Score: 2
Outcome: Failure
Key_Objection: Timing
Feedback: The seller should have acknowledged the "no" more definitively and respected the buyer's stated lack of bandwidth and priority, rather than pushing for a next step. Sentiment: Negative

parsed.feedback: The seller should have acknowledged the "no" more definitively and respected the buyer's stated lack of bandwidth and priority, rather than pushing for a next step. Sentiment: Negative
